{{pp-move|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Olivia Munn |image = Olivia Munn at PaleyFest 2013.jpg |caption = Munn at the [[Paley Center for Media]] in 2014. |birth_name = Lisa Olivia Munn |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|7|3}} |birth_place = [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]], U.S. |occupation = {{hlist| Actress| model }} |yearsactive = 2004–present |alma_mater = [[University of Oklahoma]] }}
'''Lisa Olivia Munn''' (born July 3, 1980) is an American actress and model. She began her professional career in television journalism before becoming an actress. In 2006, Munn starred as Mily Acuna on the series ''[[Beyond the Break]]''. She co-hosted ''[[Attack of the Show!]]'' from 2006 to 2010 and was a correspondent on ''[[The Daily Show]]'' from 2010 to 2011.
Munn has also had supporting roles in various films and television series since 2004. She played the character Sloan Sabbith on the television series ''[[The Newsroom (U.S. TV series)|The Newsroom]]'' from 2012 to 2014, and has appeared in the films ''[[Magic Mike]]'' (2012), the horror film ''[[Deliver Us from Evil (2014 film)|Deliver Us from Evil]]'' (2014), the comedy ''[[Mortdecai (film)|Mortdecai]]'' (2014), and ''[[X-Men: Apocalypse]]'' (2016) as [[Psylocke]]. In 2017, she provided the voice of Koko in ''[[The Lego Ninjago Movie]]'', and also had a lead role on the [[History (U.S. TV network)|History Channel]] series ''[[Six (TV series)|Six]]'' (2017).
==Early life== Lisa Olivia Munn was born July 3, 1980<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.upi.com/Famous-birthdays-for-July-3-Tom-Cruise-Olivia-Munn/6681498850891/|title=Famous birthdays for July 3: Tom Cruise, Olivia Munn|date=July 3, 2017 |agency=[[United Press International]] |accessdate=June 14, 2018}}</ref> in [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]]. Her father, Winston Barrett Munn, is an American of English, Irish and German descent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eng.alostouramagazine.com/2015/05/02/style-battle-olivia-wilde-vs-olivia-munn/|title=Style Battle – Olivia Wilde Vs Olivia Munn |date=2 May 2015}}</ref> Her mother, Kimberly Schmid, was born and raised in Vietnam and is of Chinese descent.<ref name=shattuck>{{cite web|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/25/movies/olivia-munn-has-a-fallback-plan-neurosurgery.html|accessdate=June 16, 2018|date=November 25, 2016|title=Olivia Munn Has a Fallback Plan: Neurosurgery|last=Shattuck |first=Kathryn}} {{closed access}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2016/01/08/aaron-rodgers-impresses-olivia-munns-mom-vietnamese-blogs/|title=Aaron Rodgers impresses Olivia Munn's mom, Vietnamese blogs|website=New York Post|first=Jaclyn|last=Hendricks|date= January 8, 2016|accessdate=October 27, 2016}}</ref> Her mother was a Vietnamese refugee who fled to Oklahoma in 1975 after the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name="Moviefone">{{cite web| title= Olivia Munn Facts: 29 Things You (Probably) Don't Know About the Actress| website= [[Moviefone]]|url=http://www.moviefone.com/2014/07/04/olivia-munn-facts/|date=July 4, 2014}}</ref> After college, her mother married Winston.<ref name= oceandrive>{{cite news |url=http://oceandrive.com/personalities/articles/olivia-munn-hollywoods-hottest-geek|title=Olivia Munn: Hollywood's Hottest Geek| newspaper= Ocean Drive|last= Pacheco| first= Patrick|date=May–June 2012|accessdate=September 15, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.zimbio.com/Olivia+Munn/articles/60/Tokyo+Dance+Trooper+G4TV+Olivia+Munn |title=Tokyo Dance Trooper with G4TV's Olivia Munn| website= ZimBio.com| accessdate= May 5, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| first= Christopher John |last= Farley |date=June 5, 2010| url= https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/06/05/daily-show-correspondent-olivia-munn-on-joining-the-show/ |title= 'Daily Show' Correspondent Olivia Munn on Joining the Program|newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]]| accessdate= June 5, 2012}} {{closed access}}</ref>
When Munn was two years old, her parents divorced and her mother remarried to a member of the [[United States Air Force]]. Although the family relocated many times, Munn was predominantly raised on [[Yokota Air Base]] near [[Tachikawa]] in [[Tokyo]], Japan,<ref name=about>{{cite web|url=http://www.oliviamunn.com/about/|title=About|first= Olivia |last= Munn |authorlink=Olivia Munn| website=OliviaMunn.com| publisher=COMPLEXMediaNetwork| archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5onUdX7G5?url=http://www.oliviamunn.com/about/| archivedate= April 6, 2010 | accessdate=April 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name="G4">{{cite interview| subject= Munn, Olivia|interviewer=sjohnson|title=Just Who is Olivia Munn?|website=G4TV|date= April 7, 2006 |url= http://www.g4tv.com/attackoftheshow/blog/post/577916/Just_Who_is_Olivia_Munn.html| accessdate=October 28, 2007}}</ref> where her stepfather was stationed. During this time, she appeared in a number of local theater productions and later became a model in the Japanese fashion industry.<ref name="Ask">{{cite web| title= Olivia Munn| website= AskMen.com|url=http://www.askmen.com/women/models_300/395c_olivia_munn.html|accessdate=October 28, 2007}}</ref> She has said that her stepfather was "verbally abusive" and demeaning.<ref>{{Citation |url= https://oceandrive.com/olivia-munn-hollywoods-hottest-geek |magazine=Ocean Drive |title= Olivia Munn: Hollywood's Hottest Geek |first= Patrick |last= Pacheco |date=May 1, 2012 }}</ref> Munn has two brothers, John, a physicist, and James, a custom motorcycle shop owner. She also has a sister named Sara, who is a lawyer.<ref>{{cite interview |work=The Tonight Show|interviewer=[[Jimmy Fallon]]|date=October 31, 2014|last=Munn|first=Olivia|publisher=NBC|accessdate=June 15, 2018|title=Olivia Munn Is the Family Disappointment}} {{Youtube|zUNYoy6x5Rk}}.</ref>
Her mother and stepfather divorced when Munn was a teenager, and she moved back to Oklahoma with her mother, where she attended [[Putnam City North High School]] for her junior and senior years of high school.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsok.com/article/3533333 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205081338/http://newsok.com/article/3533333 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 5, 2011 |date=January 21, 2011 |title=OU graduate Olivia Munn gets 'Perfect' in new show |website=NewsOK |accessdate=January 21, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.putnamcityschools.org/District/DistrictHistory/BooksbyPutnamCityGraduates.aspx| title= Books by Putnam City Graduates|publisher=Putnam City Schools|accessdate= April 1, 2016}}</ref> After graduating, Munn attended the [[University of Oklahoma]], where she earned a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[journalism]] with a minor in [[Japanese language|Japanese]] and dramatic arts.<ref name=shattuck/><ref>{{cite web |website=The Wrap|url=https://www.thewrap.com/newsroom-olivia-munn-puts-her-journalism-degree-use-video-102891/|accessdate=June 16, 2018|title=With 'The Newsroom,' Olivia Munn Puts Her Journalism Degree to Use|date=July 24, 2014|last1=Keavy |first1= Madisen |last2=Papenhausen |first2=Sydney }}</ref>
==Career== ===2004–2009: Beginnings=== [[File:Olivia Munn.JPG|thumb|upright|Munn signing autographs for ''Attack of the Show!'' at the 2007 Comic Con]] After graduating, she became an intern at [[KJRH-TV|the NBC affiliate]] in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]],<ref>[//www.youtube.com/watch?v=bsBF1ZPRWMY "Olivia Munn & Sam Roberts on News Room, Magic Mike, Nude Scene, Leaving G4, & more"]. [[YouTube]]. June 27, 2013. Retrieved August 25, 2013.</ref> and later moved to [[Los Angeles]] to pursue an acting career. In 2004, Munn interned at [[Fox Sports Networks]] and worked as a [[sideline reporter]] for college football and women's basketball. She has gone on to say that she disliked the experience, explaining, "I was trying to be something I wasn't, and that made me really uncomfortable on live TV."<ref name="G4"/> Soon after she moved to Los Angeles, Munn was cast in a small role in the [[direct-to-video]] [[horror film]] ''[[Scarecrow Gone Wild]]''. She appeared in rock band [[Zebrahead]]'s music video for their song "Hello Tomorrow" as the love interest of the lead singer [[Justin Mauriello]].<ref>{{youtube|Epe2dfFwSVo|Olivia Munn in Zebrahead Music Video}} Retrieved 6 December 2008.</ref> Munn also appeared in ''National Lampoon's Strip Poker'', which was filmed at [[Hedonism Resorts|Hedonism II]], a [[naturism|naturist]] resort in [[Negril]], [[Jamaica]], with [[Kato Kaelin]]. The films aired on [[DirecTV]] and [[In Demand]] [[pay-per-view]].
In late 2005, Munn began her role as teen surfer Mily Acuna over two seasons of the television drama ''Beyond the Break'' on [[TeenNick|The N network]].<ref name="g4tv">{{cite web|first=Stephen A. |last=Johnson|date=April 15, 2006|url=http://www.g4tv.com/attackoftheshow/features/53663/AOTS_hosts_Kevin_Pereira_and_Olivia_Munn.html|title=AOTS hosts Kevin Pereira and Olivia Munn|publisher=G4TV|accessdate=October 31, 2007}}</ref> She enjoys surfing and continues to practice the sport.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bean |first=Matt |title=Adventure as Aphrodisiac |website=menshealth.com|url= http://www.menshealth.com/cda/article.do?site=MensHealth&channel=sex.relationships&category=couples&conitem=70f3dce9c5443110VgnVCM20000012281eac____&page=1| accessdate=October 29, 2007}}</ref> She originally auditioned for the role of Kai Kealoha, but the producers wanted a "local girl".<ref name="blog013107"/> She also appeared in the film ''The Road to Canyon Lake''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.beautyworldnews.com/articles/9245/20140514/newsroom-actress-olivia-munn-dating-green-bay-packers-quarterback-aaron-rodgers.htm|title='The Newsroom' actress Olivia Munn dating Green Bay Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers|first=Amber|last=Belus|publisher=Beauty World News|date=May 14, 2014|accessdate=April 1, 2016}}</ref>
In 2006, Munn moved on to the [[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4 network]], where she began co-hosting ''Attack of the Show!'' with [[Kevin Pereira]] on 10 April. She replaced departing host Sarah Lane. The network, devoted to the world of video games and the video games lifestyle, was at first hesitant to hire Munn. Although she admits video games were her "weak point", she was confident in her technical knowledge.<ref>"Playboy after hours – babe of the month" (February 2007) ''[[Playboy]]'', as seen in: {{cite news|title=Olivia Munn in Playboy!|publisher=[[G4 (U.S. TV channel)|G4]]|date=January 18, 2007|url=http://www.g4tv.com/attackoftheshow/blog/post/672882/Olivia_Munn_in_Playboy.html|accessdate=October 28, 2007}}.</ref> On the show, Munn was featured with journalist [[Anna David (journalist)|Anna David]] in a segment called "In Your Pants", which deals with sex and relationship questions from viewers. While working on ''Attack of the Show!'', Munn hosted ''[[Formula D]]'', a now defunct program about American [[drifting (motorsport)|drift racing]], and an online [[podcast]] called ''Around the Net'', formerly known as ''The Daily Nut'', for G4. Munn left ''Attack of the Show!'' in December 2010 and was replaced by [[Candace Bailey]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/olivia-munn-aots-1027663/ |title=Olivia Munn: Why I Left 'Attack Of The Show' |first=Kate|last=Stanhopet|date=January 13, 2011|access-date= April 1, 2016}}</ref> Munn appeared in the [[Rob Schneider]] film ''[[Big Stan]]'' (2007). She played Schneider's character's receptionist Maria.<ref name="G4"/> Munn had a significant role in the horror film ''[[Insanitarium]]'' in which she played a nurse at an insane asylum.
===2010–present: Breakthrough=== [[File:Olivia Munn 2013.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Munn at the 2013 ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'' Women of the Year Awards]] She had roles in the films ''[[Date Night]]'' (2010) and ''[[Iron Man 2]]'' (2010). [[Robert Downey, Jr.]] praised Munn for her improvisation skills and led the crew in a round of applause.<ref>{{cite web|date=December 14, 2009|first=Blair |last=Marnell|title=Olivia Munn Talks 'Iron Man 2' Improv| url=http://splashpage.mtv.com/2009/12/14/olivia-munn-talks-iron-man-2-improv/ |work=MTV Splash Page|publisher=Viacom| accessdate=May 9, 2010}}</ref> Munn hosted [[Microsoft]]'s Bing-a-thon, an advertisement on [[Hulu]] for the Microsoft search-engine [[Bing (search engine)|Bing]], on 8 June 2009, alongside [[Jason Sudeikis]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2009/06/02/bingathon/|title=Bing-a-thon on mashable.com}}</ref> Munn appeared in [[ABC Family]]'s ''[[Greek (TV series)|Greek]]'', portraying Cappie's love interest, Lana. In May 2010, [[NBC]] announced that Munn would star on the television series ''[[Perfect Couples]]''. The half-hour romantic comedy premiered on January 20, 2011.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.nbc.com/news/2010/05/12/nbc-announces-pickup-of-new-comedy-series-perfect-couples-for-2010-11-season/ |title=NBC Announces Pickup of New Comedy Series 'Perfect Couples' For 2010–11 Season |date=May 12, 2010 |publisher=[[NBC Universal]] |accessdate=May 12, 2010 |archivedate=May 14, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514084406/http://www.nbc.com/news/2010/05/12/nbc-announces-pickup-of-new-comedy-series-perfect-couples-for-2010-11-season/ |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The series was cancelled before it completed its first season run.<ref>{{cite web|last=Zap |first=Claudine|date=April 8, 2011|url=https://tv.yahoo.com/blog/byebye-perfect-couples-hello-paul-reiser-show--2722|title=Bye-Bye, 'Perfect Couples,' Hello 'Paul Reiser Show'|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110417194925/https://tv.yahoo.com/blog/byebye-perfect-couples-hello-paul-reiser-show--2722 |archive-date=April 17, 2011 |work=[[Yahoo! TV]]|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref>
On June 3, 2010, Munn debuted in her new role as a correspondent on [[Comedy Central]]'s ''The Daily Show''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/06/olivia-munn-daily-show-coorespondant-.html |title=Olivia Munn 'trying out' as 'Daily Show' correspondent |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=June 3, 2010 |accessdate=June 4, 2010 |archivedate=June 7, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100607172818/http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/06/olivia-munn-daily-show-coorespondant-.html |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Her hiring prompted criticism from [[Irin Carmon]] of ''[[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]]'', who questioned Munn's credentials and said the show's production was [[sexism|sexist]] for hiring Munn, whom Carmon said was a [[sex symbol]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Carmon |first=Irin|url=http://jezebel.com/5558063/olivia-munns-geek-goddess-schtick|title=Olivia Munn's Geek Goddess Schtick|website=[[Jezebel (website)|Jezebel]]|date= June 8, 2010|accessdate= July 9, 2010}}</ref> Carmon said Munn's hiring was a perpetuation of the show production office's history as a male-dominated atmosphere marginalizing and alienating to women.<ref>{{cite web|last=Carmon |first= Irin |date=June 23, 2010|url=https://archive.is/20120712200020/http://jezebel.com/5570545/|title=The Daily Show's Woman Problem|website=Jezebel|accessdate=May 2, 2018}}</ref> A group of thirty-two female ''Daily Show'' production staff members said Carmon's piece was inaccurate and misinformed. Munn said that Carmon's assertion was an insult both to her and to the rest of the ''Daily Show'' staff.<ref>Abrams-Maidenberg, Teri et al. (June 2010) {{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyshow.com/message |title=Women of The Daily Show Speak |publisher=''The Daily Show'' |accessdate=December 25, 2011 |archivedate=January 16, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120116134415/http://www.thedailyshow.com/message |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>Hepola, Sarah (July 7, 2010). [http://www.salon.com/books/int/2010/07/07/olivia_munn_interview/index.html "Olivia Munn: 'I'm easy to hate. I get it'"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100709101426/http://www.salon.com/books/int/2010/07/07/olivia_munn_interview/index.html |date=July 9, 2010 }}. [[Salon.com]]. Retrieved July 12, 2010.</ref> She went on to appear in 16 more episodes as a correspondent, with ''[[TV Guide]]'' naming her signature segment "Tiger Mothering," in which she mocked the high expectations of Chinese mothers, in part by interviewing her own mother.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rudolph |first=Ileane|date=July 27, 2015|title=Alumni Association: A roundup of ''The Daily Show''{{'}}s coolest Graduates|magazine=[[TV Guide]]|pages=21–22|issn=0039-8543}}</ref> Her last episode as a correspondent aired September 2, 2011. She returned for a brief segment in host [[Jon Stewart]]'s final show on August 6, 2015.
In 2010, Munn guest-starred on NBC's comedy-drama ''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]]'' as a [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] agent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/olivia-munn-chuck-1020777/|title=Her Quest for World Domination Continues: Olivia Munn to Guest-Star on Chuck|newspaper=[[TV Guide]]|accessdate= July 21, 2010}}</ref> In 2011, Munn appeared in the comedy film ''[[I Don't Know How She Does It]]'' (2011) as Momo. In 2012, Munn had a leading role in ''[[The Babymakers]]'', a minor role in ''[[Freeloaders (film)|Freeloaders]]'', and appeared in ''Magic Mike'', directed by [[Steven Soderbergh]]. She played Sloan Sabbith on [[HBO]]'s drama series ''The Newsroom''. She also appeared as Angie, Nick's stripper girlfriend, in three episodes in Season Two of FOX's sitcom ''[[New Girl]]''.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Cabin|series=New Girl|date=January 8, 2013|network=FOX}}</ref>
Munn served as a correspondent in "True Colors," the May 12, 2014 episode of the Showtime documentary series ''[[Years of Living Dangerously]]'', in which she interviewed Washington State Governor [[Jay Inslee]] about his efforts to reduce CO<sub>2</sub> emissions in his home state. As of June 2014, Munn has been hired as the main promoter of Proactiv acne cleanser products starring in several commercials and one infomercial for the product. The commercials show Munn experiencing acne herself. Since January 2015, she has been the voice of the character Phoebe Callisto on the [[Disney Junior]] animated series ''[[Miles from Tomorrowland]]''. In 2016, Munn was cast as [[Psylocke|Elizabeth Braddock / Psylocke]] (one of [[Apocalypse (comics)|Apocalypse]]'s Four Horsemen) in ''[[X-Men: Apocalypse]]'' and will reprise the role in 2019's ''[[Dark Phoenix (film)|X-Men: Dark Phoenix]]''.
Beginning in 2017, she has a starring role in the television series ''[[Six (TV series)|Six]]'' as a [[CIA]] operative.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Culture/olivia-munn-opens-returning-tv-cias-best-operative/story?id=55479012|network=ABC News|title= Olivia Munn opens up about returning to TV as 'the CIA's best operative'|accessdate=June 14, 2018}}</ref>
In 2018, Munn appeared on [[America's Got Talent (season 13)|Season 13]] of [[America's Got Talent]] as a guest judge in the Judge Cuts 2 episode.
==In print== [[File:Olivia Munn & Joel McHale (13950135434).jpg|thumb|Munn with ''Deliver Us from Evil'' co-star [[Joel McHale]] at the 2014 WonderCon]] Munn has appeared in advertising campaigns for [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]], [[Pepsi]] and [[Neutrogena]]. She appeared on the Fall 2006 cover of ''Foam'' magazine in September, in ''Men's Edge'' magazine in August, and was featured in a pictorial in ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' in November 2006, where she later became a columnist.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.complex.com/CELEBRITIES/Profiles/Olivia-Munn|title=Complex's New Columnist: Olivia Munn|publisher=Complex|accessdate=December 6, 2008}}</ref> In February 2007, she appeared as "Babe of the Month" in a non-nude pictorial in ''[[Playboy (magazine)|Playboy]]'' magazine.<ref name="blog013107">{{cite web|last=Munn |first= Olivia |authorlink=Olivia Munn |title=Hello TV Land!! |magazine=[[TV Guide]]| date=January 31, 2007 |url=http://community.tvguide.com/blog/Celebrity-Blogs/Olivia-Attacks-Blog/700011216 |accessdate=October 31, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071027162317/http://community.tvguide.com/blog/Celebrity-Blogs/Olivia-Attacks-Blog/700011216 |archivedate=October 27, 2007 }}</ref> She discusses this shoot in her book ''Suck it, Wonder Woman''.<ref>Hess, Amanda (June 30, 2010). [http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/sexist/2010/06/30/consent-and-manipulation-in-olivia-munns-playboy-shoot/ "Consent and Manipulation in Olivia Munn's Playboy Shoot"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160423164153/http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/sexist/2010/06/30/consent-and-manipulation-in-olivia-munns-playboy-shoot/ |date=April 23, 2016 }}. ''[[Washington City Paper]]''. Retrieved June 6, 2012.</ref>
Munn also appeared in the July/August 2007 issue of ''[[Men's Health (magazine)|Men's Health]]''. In September 2007, she was featured in the Italian ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' for their "Hot Young Hollywood" Issue. Munn appeared in the Winter/Spring 2009 issue of ''Men's Health Living''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.menshealthliving.com/learn/My-Bedroom-Olivia-Munn.php |last=Vontz |first=Andrew |title=Olivia Munn in Men's Health Living |publisher=Men's Health Living |accessdate= December 6, 2008 |archivedate=December 7, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207095212/http://www.menshealthliving.com/learn/My-Bedroom-Olivia-Munn.php |deadurl=yes }}</ref> She was featured as the cover girl for the July/August 2009 issue of ''Playboy'', and later on the cover of the January 2010 and February 2011 issues of ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]''. Munn appears on the cover of the January 2012 issue of ''[[FHM]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trendrabbit.com/2011/12/olivia-munn-poses-topless-for-hot-fhm-magazine-photoshoot/|title=Olivia Munn FHM Cover, January 2012|website=Trendrabbit.com}}</ref> She was voted #2 by readers on ''Maxim''{{'}}s list of their Hot 100 Women of 2012.<ref name="Maxim-2">{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/hot-100/2012|title=2012 Hot 100: The Definitive List of the World's Most Beautiful Women|publisher=''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]]''|accessdate=August 21, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Maxim2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.maxim.com/slideshow/hot-100/43451?slide=98# |title=2012 Hot 100 |publisher=''Maxim'' |accessdate=August 21, 2012 |archivedate=23 August 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120823010244/http://www.maxim.com/slideshow/hot-100/43451?slide=98%23 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
Munn's book ''Suck It, Wonder Woman: The Misadventures of a Hollywood Geek'' ({{ISBN|0-312-59105-5}}) was released on July 6, 2010. In a review for ''[[Time Out New York]]'', Olivia Giovetti said that the book offers glimpses into Munn's life, but does not go into depth.<ref>{{cite news|last==Giovetti |first= Olivia |url=http://newyork.timeout.com/arts-culture/books/74617/suck-it-wonder-woman|title=Suck It, Wonder Woman!: Munn fans rejoice, all others proceed with caution |magazine=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out New York]]|date=28 June 2010|accessdate= August 3, 2010}}</ref>
==Charity work== In 2011, Munn teamed up with Dosomething.org's Green Your School Challenge. She was a spokesperson for the campaign by filming a PSA regarding the challenge, and sat on the panel of judges that evaluated the entries.<ref>{{cite web |last=Cernansky |first= Rachel |title=Green Your School: Take The DoSomething.Org Challenge|url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2011/02/green-your-school-take-the-dosomething-challenge.php?campaign=th_rss_takeaction |website=Treehugger.com|date= February 3, 2011|accessdate=August 3, 2011}}</ref>
Munn helped [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]] with a campaign that ultimately freed a sick elephant from a touring circus. Her blog for ''[[The Huffington Post]]''<ref>Munn, Olivia (November 21, 2011). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/olivia-munn/ringling-bros-animal-abuse-elephants_b_1106802.html "Sarah Cannot Wait Another Day"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303210236/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/olivia-munn/ringling-bros-animal-abuse-elephants_b_1106802.html |date=3 March 2016 }}. ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. Retrieved June 6, 2012.</ref> was credited with encouraging fans to contact the [[United States Department of Agriculture|USDA]] on the elephant's behalf.<ref>Daily Dish (November 29, 2011). [http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2011/11/29/olivia-munn-celebrates-after-ailing-elephant-is-saved/ "Olivia Munn Celebrates After Ailing Elephant Is Saved"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304225300/http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2011/11/29/olivia-munn-celebrates-after-ailing-elephant-is-saved/ |date= March 4, 2016 }}. ''San Francisco Chronicle'' Retrieved June 6, 2012.</ref> Munn posed for PETA's "I'd Rather Go Naked Than Wear Fur" campaign in April 2010,<ref>FITSNews (April 28, 2010). [http://www.fitsnews.com/2010/04/28/olivia-munn-wants-elephants-to-run-free/ "Olivia Munn Wants Elephants To Run Free"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304185334/http://www.fitsnews.com/2010/04/28/olivia-munn-wants-elephants-to-run-free/ |date=March 4, 2016 }}. fitsnews.com. Retrieved January 13, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://www.peta.org/features/olivia-munn/ "Olivia Munn Combats Circus Cruelty"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161127204433/http://www.peta.org/features/olivia-munn/ |date=November 27, 2016 }}. [[PETA]]. Retrieved January 13, 2011.</ref> and again in January 2012.{{better source|date=June 2018}}<ref>{{cite news|last=Everett |first=Cristina|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/olivia-munn-poses-nude-peta-latest-naked-wear-fur-ad-campaign-article-1.1005682|title=Olivia Munn naked billboard for PETA's anti-fur campaign|newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]|date=January 13, 2012|accessdate=January 13, 2012}}</ref> In February 2013, Munn fronted a PETA release of new footage showing cruelty to animals in Chinese fur farms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/381117/Animals-electrocuted-strangled-and-skinned-alive-The-true-face-of-China-s-fur-farms|newspaper=[[Daily Express]]|title=Animals electrocuted, strangled and skinned alive: The true face of China's fur farms|last=Meredith |first= Charlotte |date=March 1, 2013|accessdate=June 14, 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Munn was in a relationship with [[Green Bay Packers]] quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] from 2014 to 2017.<ref name="peoplemag">{{cite web|url=http://people.com/celebrity/olivia-munn-aaron-rodgers-split/?xid=socialflow_twitter_peoplemag|title=Olivia Munn and Aaron Rodgers Break Up|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=April 7, 2017|accessdate=April 7, 2017}}</ref>
In regard to her faith and work in ''[[Deliver Us from Evil (2014 film)|Deliver Us from Evil]]'', Munn has said that "I didn't believe in the supernatural before this movie." However, the viewing of footage from the [[New York City Police Department]] of real-life [[Exorcism in Christianity|exorcisms]] changed her mind, and she has stated that "I'm a full believer [now]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hitfix.com/news/deliver-us-from-evil-made-olivia-munn-into-supernatural-believer|title=Deliver Us From Evil made Olivia Munn into supernatural believer|last=Hasty|first=Katie|date=April 25, 2014|work=[[HitFix]]|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://videos.huffingtonpost.com/entertainment/olivia-munn-says-shes-a-believer-after-working-on-deliver-us-from-evil-518205740|title=Olivia Munn Says She's a Believer After Working on 'Deliver Us from Evil'|website=[[The Huffington Post]]|accessdate=June 5, 2014}}</ref>
Munn is a [[black belt (martial arts)|black belt]] in [[taekwondo]].<ref>{{cite web|magazine=Elle|title=5 Things Olivia Munn Did to Get Her Body X-Men Ready |last=Rodulfo |first= Kristina|date=April 28, 2016|accessdate=June 14, 2018|url=http://www.elle.com/beauty/health-fitness/news/a36006/olivia-munn-x-men-training-workout/}}</ref>
In November 2017, Munn accused film director [[Brett Ratner]] of repeatedly [[sexual harassment|sexually harassing]] her over a period of several years.<ref>{{Cite news|first1=Amy|last1=Kaufman|first2=Daniel|last2=Miller|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-brett-ratner-allegations-20171101-htmlstory.html|title=Six women accuse filmmaker Brett Ratner of sexual harassment or misconduct|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=November 1, 2017|accessdate=November 1, 2017|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref>
==Filmography== {| class = "wikitable sortable" |+ Film roles |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class = "unsortable" | Notes |- | 2004 | ''[[Scarecrow Gone Wild]]'' | Girl #1 | |- | 2004 | ''National Lampoon's Strip Poker'' | Herself | |- | 2005 | ''The Road to Canyon Lake'' | Asian mob girl | |- | 2007 | ''[[Big Stan]]'' | Maria | |- | 2008 | ''[[Insanitarium]]'' | Nancy | |- | 2009 | ''[[The Slammin' Salmon]]'' | Samara Dubois | |- | 2010 | ''[[Date Night]]'' | Claw Hostess | |- | 2010 | ''[[Iron Man 2]]'' | Chess Roberts<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2010/05/iron-man-2-roundup-captain-americas-shield-olivia-munn-and-bill-gates.html| title='Iron Man 2' roundup: Captain America's shield, Olivia Munn and Bill Gates|date=May 1, 2010|first= Geoff |last= Boucher|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] ''blog''|accessdate=May 16, 2010}} A second, unnamed role played by Munn—a partygoer at Tony Stark's birthday party—was cut from the film, but it is viewable in the movie's deleted scenes on Blu-ray. According to the audio commentary, she was given the role of Chess Roberts as compensation for her party scene being cut.</ref> | |- | 2010 | ''Jedi Junkies'' | Herself | |- | 2011 | ''[[I Don't Know How She Does It]]'' | Momo Hahn | |- | 2012 | ''[[Magic Mike]]'' | Joanna | |- | 2012 | ''[[The Babymakers]]'' | Audrey Macklin | |- | 2012 | ''[[Freeloaders (film)|Freeloaders]]'' | Madeline | |- | 2014 | ''[[Unity (film)|Unity]]'' | Narrator | [[Documentary film|Documentary]] |- | 2014 | ''[[Deliver Us from Evil (2014 film)|Deliver Us from Evil]]'' | Jen Sarchie | |- | 2015 | ''[[Mortdecai (film)|Mortdecai]]'' | Georgina Krampf | |- | 2016 | ''[[Ride Along 2]]'' | Maya Cruz | |- | 2016 | ''[[Zoolander 2]]'' | Herself | |- | 2016 | ''Lifeline''<ref>{{cite web|title=Lifeline Film|url=http://www.lifelinefilm.com/|website=Lifeline Film by Armando Bo|publisher=Qualcomm Technologies, Inc.}}</ref> | Emma | [[Short film]] |- | 2016 | ''[[X-Men: Apocalypse]]'' | [[Psylocke|Elizabeth Braddock / Psylocke]] | |- | 2016 | ''[[Office Christmas Party]]'' | Tracey Hughes | |- | 2017 | ''[[The Lego Ninjago Movie|The LEGO Ninjago Movie]]'' | Misako "Koko" | Voice role |- | 2018 | ''[[Ocean's 8]]'' | Herself<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/oceans-eight-first-official-cast-photo-is-here-w463365 |title='Ocean's Eight' First Official Cast Photo Is Here! |website=[[Us Weekly]] |publisher=[[American Media, Inc.]]|first=Heidi|last=Pantalano|date=January 30, 2017|access-date=August 16, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202005829/http://www.usmagazine.com/entertainment/news/oceans-eight-first-official-cast-photo-is-here-w463365 |archivedate=February 2, 2017 |df=}}</ref> | Uncredited |- | 2018 | ''[[The Predator (film)|The Predator]]'' | Casey Bracket | |- | 2019 | ''[[Dark Phoenix (film)|Dark Phoenix]]'' | Elizabeth Braddock / Psylocke | Post-production |- |}

Role ! class = "unsortable" | Notes |- | 2006–10 | ''[[Attack of the Show!]]'' | Herself | Co-host |- | 2006–07 | ''[[Beyond the Break]]'' | Mily Acuna | Recurring role; 9 episodes |- | 2008–09 | ''[[Sasuke (TV series)|Sasuke]]'' | Herself | Competitor; 2 episodes |- | 2009 | ''[[Greek (TV series)|Greek]]'' | Lana | 4 episodes |- | 2009 | ''Dave Knoll Finds His Soul'' | Girl #1 | [[Television film]] |- | 2010 | ''[[Accidentally on Purpose (TV series)|Accidentally on Purpose]]'' | Nicole | Episode: "Face Off" |- | 2010–11 |''[[The Daily Show]]'' | Herself | Correspondent |- | 2010 | ''[[Chuck (TV series)|Chuck]]'' | [[Buy More#Greta|Greta]] | Episode: "[[Chuck Versus the Anniversary]]" |- | 2010–11 | ''[[Perfect Couples]]'' | Leigh | Main role; 13 episodes |- | 2011 | ''[[Robot Chicken]]'' | Dr. Liz Wilson | Voice role; episode: "Kramer vs. Showgirls" |- | 2012–14 | ''[[The Newsroom (U.S. TV series)|The Newsroom]]'' | Sloan Sabbith | Main role; 25 episodes |- | 2012 | ''Paulilu Mixtape'' | Katie | Episode: "Ghost Tits" |- | 2012–13 | ''[[New Girl]]'' | Angie | 3 episodes |- | 2013 | ''The High Fructose Adventures of the Annoying Orange'' | Fudgie | Voice role; episode: "Orange Say Knock You Out" |- | 2013 | ''David Blaine: Real or Magic'' | Herself | TV special |- | 2015 | ''[[Miles from Tomorrowland]]'' | Captain Phoebe Liang Callisto | Voice role; main role |- | 2015 | ''[[Repeat After Me (TV series)|Repeat After Me]]'' | Herself | Episode 1.04 |- | 2016 | ''[[Lip Sync Battle]]'' | Herself | Episode: "Olivia Munn vs. Kevin Hart" |- | 2017 | ''[[Project Runway]]'' | Guest judge | Episode: "One Size Does Not Fit All" |- |2018 |''[[23rd Critics' Choice Awards]]'' |Herself |Host |- | 2018 | ''[[America's Got Talent]]'' | Herself | Guest judge |- | 2018 | ''[[Six (TV series)|Six]]'' | Gina Cline | Main role; 10 episodes |- | 2018 | ''My [[Houzz]]'' | Herself | Episode: "My Houzz: Olivia Munn's Surprise Renovation for Her Mom" |}

revision.text:
'''Origami''' is a [[magic (illusion)|magic]] stage illusion with a Japanese paperfolding theme, designed by [[Jim Steinmeyer]]. It was originally performed in 1986 by Canadian illusionist [[Doug Henning]], using a working prop constructed by illusion builder [[John Gaughan]]. Illusionist [[David Copperfield]] later introduced presentational changes that would be widely copied by other performers. ==Effect== {{Quote box|quote=In 1986, the wonderful Doug Henning, my former boss, introduced the Origami illusion, which means that it's been twenty-five years since that debut. Of course, at that time, I had no understanding how popular or how imitated this illusion would become. For the record, there are no "plans" for the illusion; I've always licensed it through specific associates and the illusion is protected by US patent. This hasn't prevented some magicians from building, selling and performing embarrassing and inferior versions of it. And it hasn't stopped magicians from performing it when they never really understood it. But I try to remind myself that imitation, even poor imitation, is the sincerest form of flattery.|source=[[Jim Steinmeyer]] (2011){{Cite news | last = Steinmeyer | first = Jim | title = Newsletter | date = 30 March 2003 | url = http://www.jimsteinmeyer.com/newsletter/| accessdate = 27 July 2013}}|width=19.5%|align=right}} ===Doug Henning version=== ''Origami'' was first performed by Canadian magician [[Doug Henning]] in 1986. At that time, designer Jim Steinmeyer was employed as a magic consultant by Henning. In the original presentation, Henning displays a small box, 12 inches square and decorated with Japanese-style prints, on top of a thin table. He explains that the box is held together by two ivory skewers and a wooden pole. At this point, a male assistant appears on stage carrying a large mirror, which is mounted at the rear of the table and reflects the back of the box. Henning explains that the purpose of the mirror is to allow the audience to see the routine from the back. The ivory skewers and wooden pole are now removed from the box and placed against the mirror. Henning tells the audience that the ''Origami Box'' is so named because it ''"unfolds, like an Origami work of art."'' He proceeds to unfold the box into a larger orange and black box. He further explains that the box holds just as much when it is folded down small as when it is opened up large. To demonstrate, a female assistant wearing a turquoise costume appears on stage and climbs into the box. Henning points out that she barely fits inside the larger box; and then proceeds to fold the box down into its original smaller size. As he does so, he recites a short poem: {{quote| '' "A little box, proved otherwise''
'' The world at large, made small in size!"'' }} The female assistant has disappeared from the table and it seems impossible that she can be inside the 12 inch box. Henning now takes the ivory skewers and wooden pole and inserts them back into the box, cross ways, length ways, and vertically. He now rotates the table, showing the back for the first time. There is no sign of the assistant. Henning jokes that, the next time they travel, he will take his assistant as carry-on luggage. He now tells the audience that the Japanese believe that whatever can be folded can also be unfolded. As he does so, he begins to unfold the box, and recites the rest of the poem: {{quote| '' "And as they gazed, the wonder grew''
'' The more they saw, the less they knew''
'' Each fold and crease had not explained''
'' All wonders of the world contained!"'' }} The assistant emerges from the box, now dressed in a different outfit and wearing a mask. ===David Copperfield version=== David Copperfield introduced a number of presentational changes to ''Origami'' in 1989, devised by his choreographer, co-director and on-stage assistant [[Joanie Spina]]. The choreography, background music and presentational patter used in this version have all since been widely copied by other performers.http://illusionbooks.wordpress.com/tag/stage-illusions/ Copperfield displays a red box, around 12 inches square, on a thin table. It is penetrated by three Samurai swords - ''"side to side, front to back, and even from top to bottom."'' A male assistant mounts a mirror at the back of the table, and Copperfield explains that this enables the audience to ''"see the box from around the sides and from the back at all times."'' Copperfield asks the audience to watch very carefully ''"because we're going to do this very slowly."'' The lights are extinguished, leaving the stage in darkness. A musical soundtrack of [[Peter Gabriel]]'s [[Mercy Street]] plays. The lighting is slowly restored to reveal Copperfield, in silhouette, holding one of the Samurai swords. Behind him, a female assistant clothed in red is seen, sitting on the stage floor. Copperfield removes each of the swords from the box with a flourish and mounts them on a nearby rack, before unfolding the box to its expanded state. The larger box is white. Copperfield moves across to the female assistant, takes her hand and lifts her to her feet. The two embrace briefly, to the tempo of the music, and she then steps up onto the table. The two embrace again. The assistant then steps into the box, which Copperfield then folds back into a 12-inch cube. He takes each sword in turn, with a flourish, and stabs them through slits in the center of each face of the box; the first from front to back, the second from side to side, and then stands on the table to insert the third sword from top to bottom. He now rotates the table full circle to show all sides. Then he removes the swords, unfolds the box once again to its full size, and the assistant steps out onto the table unharmed. She is now wearing a white costume, matching the expanded box. Copperfield lifts her from the table and they embrace one last time as the lights are dimmed. ===Greg Frewin version=== Illusionist [[Greg Frewin]] developed a version of ''Origami'' in which a black cloth is placed over the mirror; the mirror is then broken and three of the broken shards are used to penetrate the box. Finally, the mirror is restored.http://www.wellingtonent.com/products/origami.html ==Construction== The original ''Origami'' prop was constructed by illusion builder [[John Gaughan]]. Current authorized versions are licensed to Gaughan and to Wellington Enterprises of [[New Jersey]], United States. The design of the prop is protected by [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|US Patent]] #593178, issued in 2009 and expiring in 2023. ==External links== * [http://www.google.com/patents/USD593178 Origami Illusion (current patent)], Issued May 26, 2009, US Patent No. D593178 * [http://patft1.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?patentnumber=D345595 Origami Illusion (previous patent)], Issued March 29, 1994, US Patent No. D345,595. * [http://www.google.com/patents?id=W5omAAAAEBAJ Google Patents] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Magic and Illusion}} [[Category:Magic tricks]]

{{Infobox video game | state = | image = File:Polda_1-5_cover.jpg | caption = Cover of the box set of the first five Polda games. | series = Polda | released = 1998 | genre = Adventure }}
'''''Polda''''' is a 1998 Czech adventure video game developed by Sleep Team.
== Sequels == Polda spawned five sequels between 1999–2014, developed by ZIMA software.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://games.tiscali.cz/tema/hry-ze-serie-polda-za-smsku-33444|title=Hry ze série Polda za SMSku - Games.cz|last=Tiscali|website=Games.cz|language=cs|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref>
=== Polda 2 === In 2010 the game was re-released for the iOS mobile platforms and later on Android.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://games.tiscali.cz/tema/ceske-a-slovenske-hry-pod-koly-casu-245471|title=České a slovenské hry pod koly času - Games.cz|last=Tiscali|website=Games.cz|language=cs|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref> After the original production of ''Polda 2'' fell through, the license remained in the hands of Martin Zima, and following unsuccessful legal action, Sleep Team lost any percentage of the sale of future Polda games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://games.tiscali.cz/tema/historie-adventur-4-ceska-stopa-56482|title=Historie adventur #4: česká stopa - Games.cz|last=Tiscali|website=Games.cz|language=cs|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref>
=== Polda 3 === '''''Polda 3''''' was originally intended to be the final Polda game, finishing the trilogy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-3-policista-pankrac-se-vraci-dqb-/Novinky.aspx?c=A000426_polda3000427_bw|title=Polda 3 - policista Pankrác se vrací|date=27 April 2000|website=iDNES.cz}}</ref> According to Bonusweb, the developers deceived the entire gaming community by publicly announcing that the series was over while privately working on a fourth title.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-4-8211-z-komedie-vazna-detektivka-d7f-/Novinky.aspx?c=A010918_polda4n010919_bw|title=Polda 4 – z komedie vážná detektivka?|date=19 September 2001|website=iDNES.cz}}</ref>
=== Polda 4 === '''''Polda 4''''' was released in 2002, departing from the previous artistic style by incorporating a hybrid 2D / 3D design.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-4-nove-informace-o-ctvrtem-dilu-d7h-/Novinky.aspx?c=A011125_polda4n011126_bw|title=Polda 4 - nové informace o čtvrtém dílu|date=26 November 2001|website=iDNES.cz}}</ref>
=== Polda 5 === '''''Polda 5''''' was released in 2005.
=== Polda 6 === '''''Polda 6''''' was released in 2014.
The release date for '''''Polda 7''''' is currently unknown.
== Critical reception == The first game in the series was a huge success and became a standard of Czech games.<ref name="auto"/>
Bonusweb.cz rated the first six games in the series at 91%,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-aneb-s-poctivosti-nejdriv-pojdes-dyk-/Recenze.aspx?c=A000404_polda_bw|title=Polda, aneb s poctivostí nejdřív pojdeš|date=1998-12-20|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref> 71%,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-2-c4l-/Recenze.aspx?c=A000213_polda2_bw|title=Polda 2|date=1999-11-30|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref> 72%,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-3-pankrac-agentem-cia-095-/Recenze.aspx?c=A001120_polda3_bw|title=Polda 3 - Pankrác agentem CIA|date=2000-11-20|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref> 77%,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-4-8211-soudruh-pankracov-zasahuje-dsl-/Recenze.aspx?c=A020221_polda4_bw|title=Polda 4 – soudruh Pankrácov zasahuje|date=2002-02-22|website=iDNES.cz|access-date=2018-03-20}}</ref> 60%,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-5-8211-do-petice-vseho-dobreho-dos-/Recenze.aspx?c=A051116_polda5_bw|title=Polda 5 – do pětice všeho dobrého?|date=18 November 2005|website=iDNES.cz}}</ref> and 60%<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-6-recenze-0p6-/Recenze.aspx?c=A141209_152003_bw-pc-recenze_srp|title=RECENZE: Polda 6 je jako Kameňák českého herního průmyslu|date=12 December 2014|website=iDNES.cz}}</ref> respectively.
Seven months after Polda's release, the game continued to sell successfully and hold its place in the top ten best-selling games in the Czech Republic.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bonusweb.idnes.cz/polda-2-c4l-/Preview.aspx?c=A000130_polda2pre_bw|title=Polda 2|date=29 July 1999|website=iDNES.cz}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.polda5.cz Official website]
